quiz.title: Unit 8: National Income and Circular Flow (Quiz 10)
quiz.subtitle: 8.10 Other Macro Measures: Alternative Economic Indicators (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Alternative Economic Indicators, Welfare Measures, Beyond GDP

questions.question: The Human Development Index (HDI) combines measures of:
options: Happiness, leisure time, and environmental quality
Income equality, poverty rates, and unemployment
questions.explanation: HDI combines three dimensions: health (life expectancy), education (mean years of schooling and expected years), and standard of living (GNI per capita).

questions.question: Genuine Progress Indicator (GPI) differs from GDP by:
options: Adding non-market benefits and subtracting social/environmental costs
Focusing only on financial sector activity
questions.explanation: GPI starts with personal consumption (like GDP) but adds value for non-market benefits (housework, volunteering) and subtracts costs like pollution, crime, and resource depletion.

questions.question: The Gini coefficient measures:
questions.explanation: The Gini coefficient measures income distribution inequality, ranging from 0 (perfect equality) to 1 (perfect inequality).

questions.question: Gross National Happiness (GNH) was developed in:
questions.explanation: Gross National Happiness was developed in Bhutan as an alternative to GDP, focusing on holistic development and psychological well-being.

questions.question: The Better Life Index by OECD includes which non-economic factor?
questions.explanation: The OECD Better Life Index includes work-life balance along with housing, income, jobs, community, education, environment, civic engagement, health, life satisfaction, and safety.

questions.question: Net National Product (NNP) differs from GNP by:
questions.explanation: NNP = GNP - Depreciation, representing the net production after accounting for capital consumption.

questions.question: The Happy Planet Index measures:
options: Sustainable well-being combining life satisfaction, life expectancy, and ecological footprint
questions.explanation: Happy Planet Index = (Well-being Ã— Life Expectancy) / Ecological Footprint, measuring sustainable well-being rather than just economic output.

questions.question: Which measure focuses specifically on environmental sustainability?
questions.explanation: The Ecological Footprint measures human demand on nature, comparing human consumption of natural resources with Earth's ecological capacity to regenerate them.

questions.question: The 'dashboard approach' to measuring well-being refers to:
questions.explanation: The dashboard approach uses multiple indicators (economic, social, environmental) to provide a comprehensive picture of well-being, rather than relying on a single number.

questions.question: The Social Progress Index measures a country's ability to:
options: Meet basic human needs and provide opportunity
questions.explanation: Social Progress Index measures the extent to which countries provide for the social and environmental needs of their citizens across three dimensions: Basic Human Needs, Foundations of Wellbeing, and Opportunity.

questions.question: Which measure adjusts GDP for income distribution?
questions.explanation: GDP per capita gives average income, median household income shows the middle point, and the Atkinson Index specifically measures inequality-adjusted economic well-being.

questions.question: The 'Easterlin Paradox' findings suggest that beyond a certain point:
options: Higher GDP no longer increases happiness
questions.explanation: The Easterlin Paradox shows that while economic growth increases happiness in poor countries, beyond a certain income level additional growth doesn't significantly increase happiness.

questions.question: Which organization developed the System of Environmental-Economic Accounting?
questions.explanation: The United Nations developed the System of Environmental-Economic Accounting (SEEA) to integrate environmental information with economic accounts.

questions.question: The 'capabilities approach' to welfare measurement was developed by:
questions.explanation: Amartya Sen's capabilities approach focuses on what people are able to do and be (their capabilities) rather than just their income or resources.

questions.question: Which measure includes volunteer work and household production?
questions.explanation: The American Time Use Survey provides data on time spent in various activities, allowing estimation of the value of non-market production like household work and volunteering.

questions.question: The 'Green GDP' concept attempts to:
questions.explanation: Green GDP adjusts conventional GDP by subtracting the costs of environmental degradation and resource depletion.

questions.question: Which country officially uses Gross National Happiness as a development indicator?
questions.explanation: Bhutan formally adopted Gross National Happiness as its development philosophy and primary measure of progress since the 1970s.

questions.question: The World Happiness Report ranks countries based on:
options: Multiple factors including social support and freedom
Military spending as percentage of GDP
questions.explanation: The World Happiness Report uses six key variables: GDP per capita, social support, healthy life expectancy, freedom, generosity, and absence of corruption.

questions.question: Which measure is most useful for comparing living standards across countries?
questions.explanation: GDP at purchasing power parity adjusts for price level differences between countries, providing a better comparison of actual living standards.

questions.question: The main advantage of using multiple economic indicators is that they:
options: Simplify policy decisions to one number
Provide a more comprehensive view of well-being
questions.explanation: Multiple indicators capture different aspects of well-being (economic, social, environmental) that a single measure like GDP cannot comprehensively represent.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a comprehensive understanding of alternative economic indicators and their importance in measuring well-being beyond GDP.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the main alternative measures but should review the specific components and purposes of different indicators.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: the limitations of GDP, the purpose of alternative measures, and the key components of major indicators like HDI and GPI.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that GDP has limitations in measuring welfare, and alternative indicators like HDI, GPI, and happiness measures provide more comprehensive views of well-being.
